EBDA2E5F6CC54EF5B339C77C4E122051.description: Use examples or textual evidence from the work to support conclusions.

266D7445A6F84C68957E3E8B159199CB.description:
Articulate an understanding of several ideas or images communicated by the literary
work.

E384D0337DBA4E0189186BE9A932E141.description: Develop the topic with simple facts, details, examples, and explanations.

F4CE47049837454D88C70483F65BB394.description: Establish a controlling idea or topic.

553E72244344425888D298ABA9955FCB.description: Frame questions to direct the investigation.

876A32864E124AB190332C559EB55E41.description: Deliver informative presentations about an important idea, issue, or event by the following means:

5843E98AFC5D4DDF821EF08BBBEE0A1E.description: Show, rather than tell, the listener what happens.

B7AE5C1764B447459277257DBFF81A37.description: Establish a situation, plot, point of view, and setting with descriptive words and phrases.

F6EA2A99FC8B4425B097CD6953F404DC.description:
Using the speaking strategies of grade five outlined in Listening and Speaking Standard 
1.0, students:

F0844C23EEB6403C9802F0EC14130495.description: Students deliver well-organized formal presentations employing traditional rhetorical strategies (e.g., narration, exposition, persuasion, description). Student speaking demonstrates a command of standard American English and the organizational and delivery strategies outlined in Listening and Speaking Standard 1.0.

B4101ED5D37148B893F0A1C06260866C.description: Analyze media as sources for information, entertainment, persuasion, interpretation of events, and transmission of culture.

5713A3189B254C1981D090C5C495339C.description: Identify, analyze, and critique persuasive techniques (e.g., promises, dares, flattery, glittering generalities); identify logical fallacies used in oral presentations and media messages.

01FC2BD817724AA7A71AEA1138956670.description: Analysis and Evaluation of Oral and Media Communications

EA2E16EF15A8419F920A92EFDE801AB6.description: Engage the audience with appropriate verbal cues, facial expressions, and gestures.

A5EACEEF967749DB8A0AF6F2A59D454D.description: Clarify and support spoken ideas with evidence and examples.

769180A16E3A4936A5D10FDAAE4EA687.description: Select a focus, organizational structure, and point of view for an oral presentation.

37E2B69C5E6A4C2FB2E28726AE6BF088.description: Organization and Delivery of Oral Communication

EC113F7F653B451192E26A95AD96CE98.description: Make inferences or draw conclusions based on an oral report.

983E1C5125F14A0592FB4EAC9C189D83.description: Interpret a speaker's verbal and nonverbal messages, purposes, and perspectives.

ADC27CBD1C3B4A8DB9A12DE93AF7CC3F.description: Ask questions that seek information not already discussed.

D4AB26A92D5847D288B7F9EA16385C1F.description: Students deliver focused, coherent presentations that convey ideas clearly and relate to the background and interests of the audience. They evaluate the content of oral communication.

D4511545503644DC8825E839896B3A45.description: Spell roots, suffixes, prefixes, contractions, and syllable constructions correctly.

49240B49DD2D4B01A420851C4CD54758.description: Use a colon to separate hours and minutes and to introduce a list; use quotation marks around the exact words of a speaker and titles of poems, songs, short stories, and so forth.

43C3FAED1FE44BA1B2CD9A9B0104B937.description: Identify and correctly use verbs that are often misused (e.g., lie/lay, sit/set, rise/raise), modifiers, and pronouns.

481A4ABD0DE74A7BB9956E3386A8A723.description: Identify and correctly use prepositional phrases, appositives, and independent and dependent clauses; use transitions and conjunctions to connect ideas.

23230A34D9544E55960293B8977C432D.description:
Written and Oral English Language Conventions
Students write and speak with a command of standard English conventions appropriate to this grade level.

0D68B7E2E88C49F198D9670793037657.description: Written and Oral English Language Conventions

8494E393F417462AA4B018FB8A2BC087.description: WRITTEN AND ORAL ENGLISH LANGUAGE CONVENTIONS

9962A6C4E97645B680182078D88551D0.description: Support a position with relevant evidence.

B0D0E0E2B7184271871165F9A949A85E.description: State a clear position in support of a proposal.

151DB70AF23643C3B03CD2A52C820363.description: Develop the topic with simple facts, details, examples, and explanations.

300755B3867040ABA2A001F04C53CA7A.description: Establish a controlling idea or topic.

F3F3C48F491A4A38AC76D4E748800E42.description: Frame questions that direct the investigation.

FDA1217E300D45BF895D3C460ABE92B2.description: Write research reports about important ideas, issues, or events by using the following guidelines:

110870CBF6C84C76AD381068D76B5846.description: Develop interpretations that exhibit careful reading and understanding.

36C2404CB9B74F8C9DC2575AABF05E5C.description: Support judgments through references to the text and to prior knowledge.

8192E5DC37FE4C2EAC6B64C190CE9ADA.description: Demonstrate an understanding of a literary work.

3E95E0B34CD643829AC79087428C91FF.description: Show, rather than tell, the events of the story.

1E60A188242144939C1ED7B2C60E45B4.description: Establish a plot, point of view, setting, and conflict.

E8084613BB914564A96A8B66E92A2D36.description: Using the writing strategies of grade five outlined in Writing Standard 1.0, students:

BA0B0E896BB2471598042623DC8EF29B.description:
Students write narrative, expository, persuasive, and descriptive texts of at least 500 to
700 words in each genre. Student writing demonstrates a command of standard Ameri-
can English and the research, organizational, and drafting strategies outlined in Writing
Standard 1.0.

309D77BFFFA540688D292A040AFC2A2A.description: Edit and revise manuscripts to improve the meaning and focus of writing by adding, deleting, consolidating, clarifying, and rearranging words and sentences.

FFF1ABAA3F7B4265AA1CCE0E80769880.description: Use a thesaurus to identify alternative word choices and meanings.

1A84871DB93A49329A3B7C9C13C1B306.description: Create simple documents by using electronic media and employing organizational features (e.g., passwords, entry and pull-down menus, word searches, a thesaurus, spell checks).

14C92ED8BC524C37A20F995C1D7A60E5.description: Use organizational features of printed text (e.g., citations, end notes, bibliographic references) to locate relevant information.

B38E53E4CFB54299935063C9895E303F.description: Offer a concluding paragraph that summarizes important ideas and details.

D5C21E0F884D4FBD9CA261FBD8097C16.description:
Provide details and transitional expressions that link one paragraph to another in a
clear line of thought.

01F5A6366FEC4FB1B9BACBAF808E47F6.description: Establish a topic, important ideas, or events in sequence or chronological order.

BA85849DD3834979916CE026CE9514D5.description: Establish and develop a situation or plot.

4E8A3459964C4821BBA55491578D8314.description:
Students write clear, coherent, and focused essays. The writing exhibits the students' awareness of the audience and purpose. Essays contain formal introductions, supporting evidence, and conclusions. Students progress through the stages of the writing process
as needed.

6B527AEC778E4BD1A39AC8B6AE4FA430.description: Evaluate the author's use of various techniques (e.g., appeal of characters in a picture book, logic and credibility of plots and settings, use of figurative language) to influence readers' perspectives.

B3B9011092B348B8997F582E6AA1354D.description: Evaluate the meaning of archetypal patterns and symbols that are found in myth and tradition by using literature from different eras and cultures.

CCFF2E8EBB684063AD316F1F217D6001.description:
Describe the function and effect of common literary devices (e.g., imagery, metaphor,
symbolism).

8E85CD97ED004417877E82809D33EA74.description:
Understand that theme refers to the meaning or moral of a selection and recognize themes
(whether implied or stated directly) in sample works.

A0B787A4AC0543B596FDDFF5A1A4AB97.description:
Contrast the actions, motives (e.g., loyalty, selfishness, conscientiousness), and appearances of characters in a work of fiction and discuss the importance of the contrasts to the
plot or theme.

DC78B3CE979C4CD898861020ADD4906C.description: ldentify the main problem or conflict of the plot and explain how it is resolved.

3446492B9AF543E98420D2F32AEB1B42.description: ldentify and analyze the characteristics of poetry, drama, fiction, and nonfiction and explain the appropriateness of the literary forms chosen by an author for a specific purpose.

F74B347FCC454621BF9821CF90E93E61.description: Students read and respond to historically or culturally significant works of literature. They begin to find ways to clarify the ideas and make connections between literary works. The selections in Recommended Literature, Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve illustrate the quality and complexity of the materials to be read by students.

ED9150A6E1A54A22A7EF3AC86D776FA9.description: Distinguish facts, supported inferences, and opinions in text.

69101A72A44C4138AB95D68D0B8B6B92.description: Draw inferences, conclusions, or generalizations about text and support them with textual evidence and prior knowledge.

20A97FE39EEC4EEC8A529DA007930312.description: Discern main ideas and concepts presented in texts, identifying and assessing evidence that supports those ideas.

5504480638A64B00899FBA3F8E970440.description: Comprehension and Analysis of Grade-Level-Appropriate Text

FF9376E590A9464C873FD92AAF8AFF8E.description: Analyze text that is organized in sequential or chronological order.

4161A8D0E84C4A83BD943D539D836DFF.description: Understand how text features (e.g., format, graphics, sequence, diagrams, illustrations, charts, maps) make information accessible and usable.

A91E1B700E254A4FA4B28158DBBDC518.description: Students read and understand grade-level-appropriate material. They describe and connect the essential ideas, arguments, and perspectives of the text by using their knowledge of text structure, organization, and purpose. The selections in Recommended Literature, Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve illustrate the quality and complexity of the materials to be read by students. In addition, by grade eight, students read one million words annually on their own, including a good representation of grade-level-appropriate narrative and expository text (e.g., classic and contemporary literature, magazines, newspapers, online information). In grade five, students make progress toward this goal.

A75E821697EB46FFA29C4F41AD9BDC68.description: Understand and explain the figurative and metaphorical use of words in context.

3A3CBA87DEEA4A3D8642A94B68F20942.description:
Know abstract, derived roots and affixes from Greek and Latin and use this knowledge to
analyze the meaning of complex words (e.g., controversial).

B8B4DE743F4748E8A1F21F51490EEB93.description: Understand and explain frequently used synonyms, antonyms, and homographs.

97EE41D84B594A2F9D270064F479DC76.description: Use word origins to determine the meaning of unknown words.

C270CF21F276419793238D898418651B.description: Read aloud narrative and expository text fluently and accurately and with appropriate pacing, intonation, and expression.

3BB1FE69A9664BA6A2FB72E3AABE7DC9.description: Students use their knowledge of word origins and word relationships, as well as historical and literary context clues, to determine the meaning of specialized vocabulary and to understand the precise meaning of grade-level-appropriate words.

C32EDBB07FA84628934BE8BB8A40B0A9.description: Word Analysis, Fluency, and Systematic Vocabulary Development
